Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Sheaths and Pre-Sheaths in Magnetized and Unmagnetized Plasmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the physical properties of a near-surface layer of a plasma, a plasma sheath, which forms when a solid body is placed into a plasma. Plasmas are gases consisting of free ions and electrons; they are abundant in the universe, have many industrial applications and are the critical component of controlled fusion research. Nearly a half of the manufacturing steps necessary to fabricate a computer microprocessor employ plasmas. The interaction of plasmas with materials depends on the region close to the surfaces known as the plasma sheath. Better understanding of sheaths will lead to improved microprocessor fabrications and might be essential in achieving controlled fusion. The tabletop experiments employed in this study are also ideal for, and will greatly contribute to, training of students in the field of plasma physics and other STEM fields.

Proposed new and continuing experiments are aimed at establishing the basic properties of sheaths and associated presheaths, which accelerate ions to the sheath. The specific questions that will be addressed are: 1. What are the details of the newly recognized instability-enhanced collisional friction? 2. What happens to the anisotropy of ion velocity distribution functions (IVDFs) along the presheath and at the sheath-edge? 3. Why do experimental transverse IVDF results differ from simulations? 4. Are the ions in three species weakly collisional plasmas all lost at the system sound velocity when they have comparable densities? 5. Are there separate presheaths associated with ion-neutral collisions and oblique magnetic fields? 6. How do sheaths and presheaths at dielectric and mixed boundaries differ from those at conductors? 7. Does the sheath disappear or not when a small electrode is biased to the plasma potential? Coordinated studies of these phenomena will be carried out at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and the University of San Diego. Experiments will determine the presheath and sheath plasma potential profiles and the resulting IVDFs associated with ion acceleration. Most of the experiments will be carried out in Madison and led by the PI Prof. Noah Hershkowitz. Laser induced fluorescence (LIF) diagnostic development will be carried out on both campuses and led by the Co-PI Prof. Greg Severn. Plasma parameters will be determined with two or more techniques, e.g. combinations of emissive probes, LIF, Langmuir probes, ion acoustic wave measurements, and optical emission spectroscopy. Experiments will employ hot filament multi-dipole, capacitive, inductive, and helicon sources currently in operation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plasma sheaths are non-neutral regions that form at
plasma boundaries to balance electron and ion losses. They
are a ubiquitous feature of bounded plasma. Although Langmuir introduced the terms sheath and plasma almost 100 years ago, benchmark experiments of sheath formation and associated presheaths in unmagnetized and magnetized plasma have only recently been performed. This award project was performed in collaboration with Dr. Greg Severn in the Department of Physics & Biophysics at the University of San Diego.  Our contributions are described below.

Sheath properties are of critical importance in plasma processing for ultra large scale integrated circuit (IC) fabrication that creates, for example, the IC's that power computers and cell phones.  Sheaths were first discussed in Langmuir's work in the 1920's, and in the late 1940's, Bohm showed that presheaths were needed to accelerate ions to super-sonic speeds at the sheath edge. We performed the first experiments to confirm theory in detail in single ion species plasma, eight decades after Langmuir?s pioneering studies.



In previous funding cycles, we carried out the first ever experimental studies in two ion species plasma. Ion flow at the sheath edge was not found to occur as predicted. We discovered instability-enhanced collisional friction that arises from the difference in flow speeds between ion species of different mass as they flow toward the plasma boundary, creating the sheath. Our measurements were found to agree with a new kinetic theory of the process, a process that is now thought to be inherent in all multiple ion species plasma.  In the work supported between FY15-FY18, we performed the first experiments ever studying sheath formation in 3 ion species plasma, and the first three publications in this new area of research have come out. The individual Bohm speed (super-sonic speed)  is still widely used as the default assumption in the literature for modeling ion flow to the plasma boundary in multiple ion species plasma in a wide variety of bounded plasma systems ranging from processing plasma to the scrape off layer in tokamaks. The chief result of this work is that in a 3 ion species plasma, this is generally not true.


Further experiments found evidence of instability-enhanced collisional friction in a single ion species plasma, in the neighborhood of a virtual cathode formed near a plasma boundary. All of these efforts depend sensitively on the accuracy of plasma potential measurements with a diagnostic known as the emissive probe, and  we published an important review paper regarding recommendations for best practices for this diagnostic.  Finally, near the end of the funded period we found a new effect of ion flow toward plasma boundaries that called in question the assumed accuracy of Langmuir probe measurements of plasma potentials in the presheath region of the plasma. That work is ongoing.

Many bounded plasmas of importance employ magnetic fields for plasma confinement,  and understanding sheath formation at plasma boundaries in which  magnetic fields are present is only now becoming the subject of benchmark experiments. These plasma systems are important because they are essential components for next generation energy production technology such as tokamak magnetic fusion reactors. They are also of critical importance in plasma based ion thrusters  used for station-keeping  in satellites,  which are a necessary component of the world's GPS, TV, and communication systems.  In this and previous funding cycles, we carried out the first ever studies of presheath measurements with laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) in the neighborhood of a grounded conducting electrode oriented obliquely to the ambient magnetic field.  The experiments were performed in two argon helicon experiments (MARIA at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and HELIX at West Virginia University), using LIF.  A 3D ion fluid model that accounted for ionization and charge-exchange collisions was found to accurately describe the measured ion flows in regions where the ion flux tubes intersect the boundary.   This work was original in many respects and advanced scientific knowledge of magnetic presheaths, however, the result of chief importance was this: the generally accepted magnetic presheath model, first published in the early 80's,  was shown to be invalid.


At  UW-Madison, a first generation African-American college student participated in the magnetic presheath studies. He contributed to three of the papers that resulted from this work, and has left for the Air-Force having graduated. A Pacific Islander by ancestry participated in these projects as a trainee. He left for graduate study in space propulsion, a field related to plasma physics.  Four undergraduates also participated in these projects as trainees.  Two now are in graduate school studying physics, and two now have STEM jobs. One of the graduates students is now 
working in the  Chinese Academy of Science in Hefei.
